body: @mdeuser @dubeejw Currently the new cli repo https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/ is able to build the binaries in an auto way, each time we add a tag to the master branch.

> each time we add a tag

@houshengbo - Is the tag set and updated automatically or manually?
@mdeuser Tag is done manually. There is only one tag added so far, and there is only one group of binaries on the release page.
Let's use tags, and use the tag to set the version of the CLI when compiling the binary

@dubeejw what should we use to build wsk cli if not ansible? 

I guess it depends on if we go in the same route as openwhisk-client-swift where the builds are published under GitHub/releases and have openwhisk point to the hosted binary.

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-client-swift/releases/download/0.2.3/starterapp-0.2.3.zip

Or we keep this PR as is to have openwhisk build latest binaries from openwhisk-cli.

From my perspective, downloading the latest code of go cli makes sense in ansible, since we need provide an option to build from the latest code of go cli. This is something similar we did for openwhisk-catalog in ansible.

Well, if the user likes to directly download the binary, we can also add that part into the ansible scripts. What do you think? @dubeejw @csantanapr @mdeuser

Tag needs to be created manually so the person creating the tag decides which number to bump in semver major.minor.patch  usually will be patch unless there is a feature or enhancement then minor. 
I think we should try to keep the CLI on version 1.x.y for a while for now and not have 2.x until it's really necessary

If creating a new git release automatically is not possible, let's publish the latest CLI binaries in DockerHub automatically whenever a PR is merged, and have OpenWhisk pull the latest container for every deploy using Ansible.
We use Ansible for deploying containers that are already built.
This repo can produce a CLI binary and also push docker images to docker hub as "latest" and also as "tag" version 1.x.y
Part of the benefit of removing the CLI from the OpenWhisk repo is that OpenWhisk will take less time to build as it does not have to build the CLI.
This document describes how to publish to DockerHub using Git: https://docs.docker.com/docker-hub/builds/.
@rabbah, updated the test.
@bjustin-ibm - ready for merging... @dubeejw performed actual review, but this PR needs a review record for which I do not have permissions to start that process...
@dubeejw docker hub needs an account, what is the best practice for creating such account?
What triggers the build and on what system(s) will the CLI be built?  That is, will docker hub build a docker container with the CLI?  Will another system also build the CLI?
We have a Docker account here: https://hub.docker.com/r/openwhisk/. I believe @csantanapr has the credentials.
@csantanapr is out until 4/20 :( anyone else who would have those credentials to https://hub.docker.com/r/openwhisk/?
@rabbah  had the credentials if needed also has admin for Travis

@pritidesai, @houshengbo, we don't want to use the latest CLI code with OpenWhisk that means we don't need to use DockerHub. Since the CLI is being versioned, OpenWhisk should download the latest versioned binaries from the Git releases page. If we want OpenWhisk to use a newer version of the CLI, we will have to manually tag and publish new binaries to the Git releases page.

@dubeejw @pritidesai 
I have already enabled the travis ci to build the latest binaries for go cli, and they are able to publish on the releases page automatically.

We can always access the latest version via the following links:
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases/download/latest/OpenWhisk_CLI-latest-linux-amd64.zip;
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases/download/latest/OpenWhisk_CLI-latest-darwin-amd64.zip;
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases/download/latest/OpenWhisk_CLI-latest-windows-amd64.zip

We have three binaries at this moment. They can be used in this PR to get the latest binaries.

We also have one major release available, v1.0:
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases/download/v1.0/OpenWhisk_CLI-v1.0-darwin-amd64.zip
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases/download/v1.0/OpenWhisk_CLI-v1.0-linux-amd64.zip
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases/download/v1.0/OpenWhisk_CLI-v1.0-windows-amd64.zip


The naming convention for the download link is https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases/download/<tag\>/OpenWhisk_CLI-\<tag\>-\<OS\>-amd64.zip.
PG3   #517 ok

A quiet mode would be handy for property get too. That way I wouldn't need to do this:

    wsk property get --cliversion | rev | cut -f1 | rev
@houshengbo - prior to publishing the CLI binary, have all CLI tests passed successfully?
PG2 1432 passed

Another path could be deploying openwhisk on Bosh (if your considering on premise cloudfoundry, you have bosh director).
There is already : a docker bosh release wich could be leveraged, with swarm support.
https://github.com/cloudfoundry-community/docker-boshrelease
What should be the response status code and body in this situation -  `.http` invocation of web action that does not return JSON with a `body` field?

the defaults are:

- `statusCode`: 200
- `body`: empty
- `headers`: []

the defaults apply when the properties are not defined; in the case affecting this defect, the controller is sending body `"OK"` instead of the empty response.
The fix will apply on this line: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/core/controller/src/main/scala/whisk/core/controller/WebActions.scala#L243

i would put the extra info on the right (last columns) and preserve existing format where id is first.
there are users who have scripts that process these columns, we shouldn't break them plus if there are other fields, it's better to float on the right.

What kind of caching mechanism is there for the images from dockerhub? i.e. does that introduce a delay for cold starts with large images? I’ve entered another ticket to have support for Bluemix Container Service registries, would that improve cold start times?
Travis in the CLI repo would have to pull down the latest OpenWhisk, build/deploy it then run just the CLI tests against it.
note that with the database split, the authkeys for the db will need to be split also as there may be different keys to access each table with different access roles.

Perhaps also include a duration (in ms) column..  For NLS purposes, "StartTime" -> "Start Time".
@rabbah - what bits of the activation response are needed to convey a good status summary?
- response.status (i.e. "success", ... others?)
- response.statusCode (i.e. action exit code ?)
- response.sucess  (i.e. true/false)
- response.result.statusCode (web action)
- other??

why?  won't openwhisk pull the cli binary as part of deploy (needs to be done early in deploy)?  if not then this breaks a lot of tests in many repos.  It will also break the installation scripts in many of the repos.

After talking a bit with @mdeuser, it seems like returning a 400 would be a good thing to do if the developer did not send the right format in the response from their web action.

Additionally, instead of returning an empty body, might it make sense to also return a string or something indicating that the action is misconfigured?
I would just report success/failure. To some extent this could become quite heavy. See "npm wab" for motivation.  I think getting the start time, duration, and success indicator is sufficient.

@mdeuser @dubeejw Do we currently have test cases available for CLI, in order to guarantee the CLI's and CLI binaries' quality?

There are no test code within the go-whisk and go-whisk-cli folders. There are tests written in scala in openwhisk, using the CLI binaries, but they are not the tests for CLI.
@houshengbo - Actually, the predominant CLI tests are all currently written in scala - both positive and negative tests.
Are they all located [here](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/tests/src/test/scala/whisk/core/cli/test)?
The bulk of the CLI-centric tests are in WskBasicUsageTests.scala.  I think a few other CLI tests are outside this file, but not as many
As long as the binaries are copied to the place we specified, there should be no effect on the tests in openwhisk. I will close this issue here. The CLI in the new repo may need tests.

I liked the original thought. The cli tests should move to the cli repo in near future. The tests in this repo should be API based and in fact we should use that as a way of cleaning up and enforcing our swagger compliance.
I won't reopen this issue though because we have another issue for the above which I'll cross link.

Are there any updates on this?
Is this pending until the completion of new implementation of ContainerPool?
No it isn't. We were trying to find infrastructure to setup automatic testing for a mac based deployment.
Also since this replaces the previous mac environment, all mac developers will need to update to the latest docker machine support for mac.

This is looking good!  Would be great to see a `Duration` column after the start time.

Will the Start Time column values always be displayed in the local time zone?

Does the `Name` column have a max length or will it dynamically extend to the largest action name?

The width of the name column is dynamically the length of the largest entry.

The start time is the local time.  UTC is also possible ...

@rabbah - Per our conversation

I want to now update [nginx.conf](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/roles/nginx/templates/nginx.conf.j2#L63) file so that it pulls CLI from openwhisk-cli [releases](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases/tag/latest) page. 

How do we maintain following directory structure and decompress `wsk` cli, all this being part of nginx? do we still need role for [CLI](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/ansible/roles/cli/tasks)?

```
ls /etc/nginx/cli/go/download/linux/amd64/
OpenWhisk_CLI-linux.tgz  wsk
```

surprisingly there's no test that would have caught this: where we test `wskadmin`, we create a new subject, and where we lookup a namespace for the guest or system id, we use `wskadmin user list ns`.

i suggest either additing a test that confirms `wskadmin user get` guest and system id work as expected to catch any future regressions where these keys are added manually.... or use `wskadmin` from the ansible script.
will merge post travis.
@dubeejw - Finally have a good travis!  Ready to approve?

You could just have nginx serve a json object with the links for each platform.
I never liked the way we rendered the directory anyway.
@rabbah - travis passed :-)  thanks in advance for the merge
@rabbah - any concerns?

I like it!  Minor comments
- Column header spaces.  "ActivationID" -> "Activation ID"; "StartTime" -> "Start Time"
- Add units to `Duration` header
- May just be the way the output is displayed... minor duration value alignment.. not fully right aligned.

is this strictly to cover the programmer when they fail to return `body` or an http action? if the absence of any fields, should this be treated as success of failure - since we define defaults.

i think this is more subtle and want to think it through some more.
i can imagine that such validation could happen inside an action with a validation middleware (thinking of an `express` like approach where the validation happens inside the action as user code and not in the controller.)
note that action names can be up to 256 characters long - should there be a cutoff (after 32 chars, use `...` for example)?

Yes. At first time, I tried to use `local` whick_version_name as well to make user deploy OW transparently no matter of OS.

Only this part is the issue.

**ansible/roles/invoker/tasks/deploy.yml**
```
- name: define options when deploying invoker on Ubuntu
  set_fact:
    linuxOptions: "-v /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libapparmor.so.1:/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libapparmor.so.1"
  when: whisk_version_name != "mac"
```
I could fix this `when` statement, but thought that if we keep `mac` environment for `docker-machine`, user may think ow can't be deployed on mac natively(with `local`).

So I made one more environment, docker-machine.

But as of now, I think it would be better to remove `mac` environment and keep `docker-machine` environment only.

Then user can deploy OW transparently with `local` as I intended at first.
Only someone wants to deploy OW with Docker-machine, they will use `docker-machine` environment.

In either cases, those who use `mac` currently, should change their environment.

How do you think?
Yikes.  Bad "stack overflow copying-fu".   Trying to write to stderr.  Let me fix to `>&2`

From @paulcastro: There were bugs in the JSONSerializer class on Linux so we switched to using an external library SwiftyJSON for serdes. Not sure this is the root cause but one thing to try is going back to vanilla JSONSerializer to rule out any strange SwiftyJSON behavior.

Looks like the culprit is in a recursion processing escaped strings in WhiskJSONUtils.  If I bypass that function I get 

```
real	0m0.025s
user	0m0.010s
sys	0m0.000s
```
Just looking at that as well.

I agree this gives transition time
env mac will mean future using docker for Mac
env docker-machine means depreacted env and later removed to give time for folks to updgrade to docker for Mac
Yes content.json

For reference, I work on the `IBM Watson Discovery Service` and we were using `OpenWhisk` in a hackathon yesterday where this issue came up. My IBM email is `ghart@us.ibm.com` if you have any followup questions.
You are correct. Thank you for fixing the documentation bug.
@rabbah Good catch on the space! Should be pushed now (This is my first time using the public Github fork-pull-request workflow, so let me know if something isn't working).
Ah, yes! I ran into that one too (tried to do `print json.dumps(out, indent=2)` and it failed)

We can bypass the escaped string code using the standard JSONSeralization class.  We didn't use it before because of a bug that has since been fixed.

Preliminary experiments show this time when using the JSONSerialization:

```
real	0m0.141s
user	0m0.040s
sys	0m0.020s
```
Looks good, thanks for the speedy fix 👍
@rabbah - would you mind review/merge these changes.  Travis passes and PG passes the associated tests (minus a persistent test failure at the moment)

Hi @rabbah . Just checking back in. We were hoping to finish this up this week so we can do our final promotion for Serverless Austin on Tuesday.  We don't have a strong opinion on this, but I guess I'm leaning toward your second comment so that we aren't in conflict with the defaults.

It's this line that seems to be very slow in the Swift 3.0.2 container:
`<String>.replacingOccurrences(of:"\"", with:"\\\"")`

A simple function that does a `replacingOccurences` on a large string results in:

```
real	0m12.402s
user	0m11.440s
sys	0m0.010s
```

It seems much faster in the Swift 3.1 container (PR #2120).

```
real	0m0.035s
user	0m0.010s
sys	0m0.010s

I linked to the one line that requires a change for http. The fix is to complete(StatusCodes.OK, HttpEntity.Empty). It will need an obvious test. If someone wants to send a pr I'll be happy to review and merge. I may not get to it today.
@dubeejw - can you look into this fix.  thanks!
What's the status on this?
Proposed patch in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/2148/files.

This is for `.http` web actions, where the controller passes the body intact to the action as `__ow_body`. It would recover the behavior we provide for `.json` web actions for example where the body is passes as a top level JSON object to the action as an argument.

@akrabat did I understand correctly?

I rebased this to master to pick up a performance fix in the JSON serialization and resolve conflict. Also fixed one line for python 3 syntax and removed trailing white spaces. Compare changes with `w=1`: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1993/files?w=1
Yes. For `.http` web actions, a `Content-Type` of `application/json` and `xxx/yyy+json` should behave the same.

Just to double check, but there are quite a few status codes that don't need a body and at least one that mandates that you may not have a body (`204`). Does this change break the these situations as I wouldn't want my `204` changed to a `400`…

The patch I proposed is to fix the case where a missing body resulted in a response of "OK". No when no body is present the response is no content as well. So it's consistent with the behavior you want.
Ah, I see. There's a default text that's used if there's no body and that default text is "OK" for 200, which is nonsense.
PG?
Thanks for merging. Can the Docker container be updated too please?
